channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: Canadians push back against Trump's tariffs by avoiding U.S. goods and travel
item.description: Many Canadians along the U.S. border continue to avoid purchasing U.S. goods and travel. A major grocery chain is labeling products so customers know what they are choosing.

item.title: What happened when schools paid high schoolers $50 a week, no strings attached?
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Jonathan Johnson, founder and CEO of Rooted School Foundation, about a study involving his charter schools which gave $50 weekly to low-income students.

item.title: Dungeons & Dragons live shows spawn new fans of the tabletop game
item.description: Dungeons & Dragons is a game invented in the 1970s where people sit around a table playing characters on a fantasy adventure. But over the past decade, D&D has emerged as a popular form of spectator entertainment.

item.title: Marc Maron on feeling connected to the partner he lost
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. Comedian Marc Maron talks about the ways he feels connected to the partner he lost.

item.title: The story behind one grim image of a mother and child in Gaza
item.description: A photo of a starving child in Gaza has gone viral, with many in Israel claiming it depicts false information.

item.title: Decades of songbird mapping in New Hampshire yields insights about their changing home
item.description: In 1969, a team of researchers took a patch of forest in central New Hampshire and mapped the territories of the songbirds inhabiting it. For more than half a century, that work has continued, revealing insights about the forest and its birds with evermore modern techniques.

item.title: 'Each Peach Pear Plum' author Allan Ahlberg dies at 87
item.description: Bestselling children's writer Allan Ahlberg has died at the age of 87. Many of his books -- like Each Peach Pear Plum and The Jolly Postman -- were illustrated by his wife, Janet, who died in 1990.

item.title: Fancy Farm, a Kentucky tradition, debates Sen. Mitch McConnell's legacy
item.description: An annual picnic in Kentucky became a platform for GOP Senate candidates to show how closely they align with President Trump. Some also attempted to distance themselves from Sen. Mitch McConnell.

item.title: The politics driving the push for gerrymandering
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with David Wasserman of the Cook Political Report about the impact redistricting efforts will have on the 2026 midterms and beyond.

item.title: The USDA is getting help from Hollywood to keep wolves away from cattle
item.description: To keep cattle safe, the USDA is using movie clips to scare away wolves.
